titleStmt.title: Behavioral decision research is not a Linda problem: Comment on Regenwetter, Robinson, and Wang (in press)

analytic.title: Behavioral decision research is not a Linda problem: Comment on Regenwetter, Robinson, and Wang (in press)

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Regenwetter, Robinson, and Wang (in press) argue that research on decision making is plagued with conjunction fallacies or "Linda Effects". As a case study, they provide a critical analysis of Kahneman and Tversky's seminal paper on Prospect Theory and its 1992 sequel. This commentary evaluates their criticisms and ultimately finds them to be predicated on a number of misconceptions. As argued below, a reliance on stylized effects at the aggregate level is perfectly legitimate when dismissing a received view and first proposing a new account that organizes said effects in theoretically-meaningful ways. STYLIZED CHARACTERISTICS 3 Regenwetter, Robinson, and Wang (in press), henceforth RRW, used a formal result from probability theory to motivate a conceptual and historical reconstruction of research in decision making, using the famous 1979 paper by Kahneman and Tversky and its 1992 sequel as case studies. RRW argued that research in decision making is plagued with blanket statements that ignore the ubiquity of individual differences, referring to 'people' being a certain way and doing this and that, as if these claims held true for every single person. According to RRW, such moves on the researcher's part are tantamount to conjunction fallacies-"Linda Effects". More specifically, RRW argue that there is a parallel between a) researchers operating under the supposition that most people manifest a number of "stylized characteristics", and b) the observation that participants often judge the probability of Linda being 'a feminist and a bank teller' to be greater than the probability of Linda being 'a bank teller'. The purpose of this comment is to show that RRW's piece has a number of serious problems: First, they do not appear to fully appreciate the nature of their own formal results. Also, they do not appear to be willing to engage with what specific researchers are actually saying and doing, or otherwise hold a charitable view. Category Errors and Untenable Assumptions RRW's attempt to establish an analogy with the famous "Linda Effect" (Tversky & Kahneman, 1983) turns out to be quite helpful to when trying to identify the problems with their critique. The first problem is that RRW are essentially committing a category error: The Linda Effect shows that people's judgments often refer to states

div.p: of affairs that are mathematically impossible, whereas the issue that RRW are singling out is that the marginal choice proportions comprising the different stylized characteristics are consistent with a multitude of joint choice distributions. In other words, what RRW are showing is that there is a considerable amount of uncertainty at the level of individual choice patterns. But the fact that this uncertainty includes the possibility that nobody conforms to all the stylized characteristics doesn't render alternative scenarios in which most of people do impossible.

Moreover, RRW's analysis makes untenable assumptions that lend illegitimate support to their narrative. Namely, they assume that erroneous responses are impossible, and conflate data with phenomena. To see this more clearly, let us briefly summarize the gist of their analysis. Let P (X n ) denote the probability that a randomly sampled individual manifests some binary preference X ∈ {0, 1} on lottery problem n = 1, . . . , N . Probability theory establishes that the probability of a conjunction of binary preferences across all N lottery problems; e.g., P (X 1 = 0 ∩ X 2 = 1 ∩ • • • ∩ X n = 1), has the following lower and upper bounds:
div.formula: max 0, N n=1 P (X n ) − (N − 1) Lower Bound ≤ P N n=1 X n ≤ min n {P (X n )} Upper Bound(1)
div.p: These bounds show that a conjunction of binary preferences can be rare even if the probabilities associated with each binary preference are relatively high. For example, consider the case of three lottery problems, all with probability P (X n = 1) = .75. The probability of the conjunction can range between .25 and .75. If we considered four lottery problems instead (all with P (X n = 1) = .75), the lower bound would be 0. In other words, the conjunction might be representative of almost no one, if anybody at all.
According to RRW, these bounds raise concerns about the way stylized characteristics are handled by researchers. As an example, consider the following pair of lottery problems:

.66 .01 ), $2500 $0 .33 .67 ). Kahneman and Tversky (1979) Birnbaum's (2008) "new choice paradoxes", they argue that in the best-case scenario, they only represent 57% of the people. This statement ignores the fact that allowing for the possibility of errors would increase this value. For example, if we assumed the probability of errors could go up to .30, then the best-case scenario would be raised to 68% of the people.

Moreover, RRW's analyses conflate phenomena with data (e.g., Bogen & Woodward, 1988;Woodward, 2000). Specifically, RRW are tacitly assuming that the phenomena of interest; e.g., the violation of the independence axiom, is equivalent to the observation of particular choice patterns with the lottery problems described above.

It is easy to see why this assumption is untenable: Let us assume that Prospect Theory is the correct account, and that the independence axiom is indeed violated because of the non-linear weighting of probabilities. An exploration of different non-linear weightings shows that many of them do not yield a preference reversal with these specific lottery problems-different sets of lottery problems would have to be used instead. Therefore, if we assume that people can differ in terms of their Prospect-Theory characterization -something that nobody really denies -it follows that the proportion of people manifesting a stylized characteristic with a specific lottery problem is always going to be a conservative estimate of the proportion of people that would manifest it under the right circumstances.

div.head: Engagement with the Literature
div.p: Researchers studying the Linda Effect- Tversky and Kahneman (1983) included-have made considerable efforts towards understanding what might be driving participants' judgments. For instance, some have hypothesized that the effect is driven by a misunderstanding of the connective 'and' (e.g., Hertwig, Benz, & Krauss, 2008).

Others have proposed that, rather than bona fide probabilities, participants' judgments are in fact legitimate expressions of the differential degree of support for two nested hypotheses that can be extracted from the verbal description of Linda (e.g., Crupi, Fitelson, & Tentori, 2008; see also von Sydow, 2011). The common thread between these different research efforts is the idea that one cannot readily dismiss people as irrational or incompetent. After all, it is perfectly possible that the researcher is misunderstanding participants' judgments and the normative principles that guide them (for a relevant discussion, see Skovgaard-Olsen, Kellen, Hahn, & Klauer, 2019).

Keeping with the analogy, it is unfortunate to not find anything in RRW's critique suggesting that they also indulged in any similar kind of interpretative charity. Much to the contrary, RRW painted an entire field of research with strokes so broad that it is difficult to figure out where they are placing the demarcation line. For instance, when inspecting what appears to be a list of "offenders" (large block of citations in their introduction), we do find studies that indeed rely on aggregate data without much concern for individual differences (e.g., Usher & McClelland, 2004). But we also find other studies whose only fault appears to be nothing more than a façon de parler (e.g., Fennema & Van Assen, 1998). To be clear, there is a long-spanning history of linguistic misuse in psychology and related disciplines, and many insightful analyses on this matter have been produced (e.g., Bennett & Hacker, 2003;Billig, 2013;Sharrock & Coulter, 1998;Slaney & Maraun, 2005). But given that no such analysis is provided by RRW, it is unclear whether we are dealing with mere linguistic embellishments or serious conceptual confusions.

This lack of engagement on RRW's part is further manifested in the way that they fail to consider the nature of stylized characteristics. Stylized characteristics consist of experimental demonstrations of behavioral regularities that contravene a given received view, whether that is a formal theory or the experimenter's intuitions. For instance, the paradoxes of Allais and Ellsberg are demonstrations of people's choices being consistently at odds with the axioms of Expected Utility Theory (Allais, 1953;Ellsberg, 1961), whereas Lichtenstein and Slovic's (1971) preference reversals provide a sobering lesson to anyone who might downplay the importance of how preferences are elicited.

Stylized characteristics serve two main roles: They serve as critical tests of a received view, and as demonstrations of the kind of behavioral phenomena that any new candidate theory will need to be able to accommodate (for a similar view, see Sugden, 2005; see also Garcia-Marques & Ferreira, 2011).

As tests, stylized characteristics serve to show that some people's choices deviate from the received view, to a degree that cannot be ignored. They provide the grounds for dismissal. It is easy to see why their joint occurrence is often ignored: Each stylized characteristic is by itself enough to exemplify the shortcomings of the received view. It is also clear why the distinction between data and phenomena, and the underestimation that follows from it, is often not made explicit: Highlighting that the observed proportion of violating choices is a conservative estimate, as favorable as that might be, is ultimately unnecessary. The observed proportion is enough to get the point across and move on.

When taking on a demonstrative role, stylized characteristics become a vehicle for discovery -but not so much for justification. They invite researchers to develop new theoretical proposals but do not necessarily provide the means to adjudicate between them. One way of putting it is that, as an 'empirical foundation', stylized characteristics cannot sustain much beyond dispositional ascriptions, which are far coarser than the kind of theoretical concepts that researchers often traffic in (on dispositions, see Rozeboom, 1984;Sober, 1983). This means that new empirical investigations, tailored to the specifics of each theoretical proposal; e.g., their causal claims, will be necessary for their support (e.g., Birnbaum, 2004); investigations that often rely on novel procedures that have very little to do with the original stylized characteristics (e.g., Abdellaoui, Bleichrodt, l'Haridon & Van Dolder, 2016). But one of the consequences of such moves is the decreased relevance of matters concerning the co-occurrence of stylized characteristics. After all, the stylized characteristics are not "the things" that we are really interested in at this point -the different theoretical concepts being proposed are. Wittgenstein's metaphor of a ladder that is no longer needed when one has climbed up a wall seems appropriate here.

Distinguishing between these two roles -stylized characteristics as critical tests and as demonstrations -helps us to see Tversky's 1979 and1992 papers through a glass less darkly: Kahneman and Tversky (1979) first used the stylized characteristics as separate indictments against Expected Utility Theory. Later on, when using them together to sketch Prospect Theory, Kahneman and Tversky were not necessarily trying to show that they had a single characterization that would hold for every single person, but simply demonstrating that the concepts of subjective value, loss aversion, and the non-linear weighting of probabilities altogether can organize a large number of behavioral phenomena and issue a number of promissory notes regarding future research (for a similar "organizational" approach, see Loomes, 2010; for a defense, see Rozeboom, 1997). Their 1992 sequel paper is not much different. Even though they developed a parametric implementation of Prospect Theory, they were very clear about the pragmatic motivation behind the parametric functions adopted ("This form has several useful features: it has only one parameter ... it provides a reasonably good approximation...", p. 310) 2 and their focus on qualitative performance ("we 2

The exact same thing can be said about Birnbaum's (2008) work on the TAX model, which is also criticized by RRW. The purpose of the parametric "prior TAX" is to establish how the concept of 'configural attention exchange', which is motivated by work preceding Prospect Theory, can shed light on a number of critical-test results that violate the axioms of Prospect Theory. Perhaps even more so than Tversky and Kahneman (1992), Birnbaum is very explicit about the pragmatic motivations behind focused here on the qualitative properties of the data", p. 311; "Theories of choice are at best approximate and incomplete", p. 317). 3 Since their publication, a large body of high-profile research exploring the different theoretical concepts proposed by Prospect

Theory at the individual level has been produced (e.g., Abdellaoui, Bleichrodt, & Paraschiv, 2007;Bleichrodt & Pinto, 2000;Brooks & Zank, 2005;Fennema, & Van Assen, 1998;Gonzalez & Wu, 1999;Tom, Fox, Trepel, & Poldrack, 2007, among many others).

Importantly, some of this followup work has vindicated the overall qualitative characterization that is obtained with median parameters CPT MED (but see Birnbaum, 2008). When taking this fact into account, it becomes easier to identify some of the possible reasons for using CPT MED when representing Prospect Theory (e.g., in an introduction). Rather than a strong belief in the parameters' generalizability (i.e., that they describe every single person), their use can simply reflect a mere habit or a desire to be consistent with past treatments (for relevant discussions on scientific and artistic representation, see Goodman, 1968;Van Fraassen, 2008). Another possible reason for the prevalence of CPT MED (or some variation of it) in the literature is the fact that they continue to be used in "recipes" for constructing new lottery problems designed to test Prospect Theory. Regardless of their plausibility, it is clear that these median parameters have a generative power that needn't be ignored (see Birnbaum, 2008;Kellen, Steiner, Davis-Stober, & Pappas, 2020).

div.head: Concluding Thoughts
div.p: RRW's critique is motivated by a strong concern with individual heterogeneity, a concern that I share with similar intensity (e.g., Kellen & Klauer, 2020;Kellen, Mata, & Davis-Stober, 2017;Kellen, Pachur, & Hertwig, 2016;Kellen, Winiger, Dunn, & Singmann, 2021;Singmann & Kellen, 2019). Lest we forget: The this specific parametrization of TAX, which he clearly distinguishes from the 'General TAX ' model. reality of individual heterogeneity introduces serious inferential challenges, which researchers ignore at their own peril. The point of contention here is that RRW overstate their case and that many of their arguments are predicated on an uncharitable reading of the decision making literature at large that many of its actors (and readers)

would most certainly not subscribe to. In the case of Kahneman and Tversky's work, RRW are taking them literally but not seriously. This is counterproductive, providing an opportunity for dismissing their critique wholesale, including a number of valuable insights and suggestions. Now, should one conclude from the present response that all is well in behavioral decision research? Absolutely not! 4 Like many others, I believe that there is a serious need for critical treatments of the ways behavioral decision research is conducted (for a recent plea, see Weiss & Shanteau, 2021). But the nuance and complexity of the subject matter calls for careful historical, methodological, rhetorical, and conceptual considerations that go beyond what RRW currently have to offer (see Bennett & Hacker, 2003;Gozli, 2019;Maraun, 2003;Rozeboom, 1970;Smith, 1986;Soyland, 1994;Zuriff, 1985).

figure.figDesc: to motivate the development of (Cumulative) Prospect Theory. RRW took the proportions reported by Kahneman and Tversky as error-free estimates of choice probabilities and used them to compute lower and upper bounds. In the above example, the probability

row.cell: of joint choices that are at odds with Expected Utility Theory, P ((A ∩ B ′ ) ∪ (B ∩ A ′ )),
ranges between .45 and .99. 1 In other words, it is possible that the violating choice
patterns are held by less than half of the people. Extending this analysis to all of the
stylized characteristics used by Kahenman and Tversky, RRW report that the
probability of their conjunction ranges between 0 and .85. But instead of establishing
that most generalizations about this conjunction are impossible, these bounds merely
show that the observed results are compatible with almost every possible scenario.
By assuming that no errors can occur, RRW are biasing both lower and upper
boundaries downwards. This bias can lead to unfair claims that certain stylized
characteristics might only hold together for a relatively small proportion of individuals,
even in the best-case scenario. For example, when RRW discuss

figure.note: reported that 82% of the respondents chose A over B, whereas only 17% preferred A ′ over B ′ . They argued that this result is at odds with the independence axiom postulated by Expected Utility Theory, which predicts a preference for A over B if and only if there is also a preference for A ′ over B ′ . Kahneman and Tversky reported many other such stylized characteristics, and used their conjunction

body.note: Computing this range requires us to also consider the bounds for disjunctions, which is not discussed here for reasons of space (for an overview, seeHailperin, 1986).

These quotes suggest that RRW's reading of Tversky and Kahneman's proposal and the discovered discrepancy involving lottery problem 7 is perhaps too strong. One of the costs of adopting a specific parametrization is the occasional empirical failure. This isn't necessarily fatal (seeKellen, 2019;Navarro, 2019).
In fact, I would argue that the study of context effects, which RRW briefly discuss at some point, would have been a much more suitable target for their critique.
